awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Scalable and Flexible Algorithms to Detect Structural Change in Complex Sequence Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern technologies in science and engineering generate data that become bigger in size and more complex in content. It is important and challenging to understand such data using statistical and computational methods, especially to identify trends in the data. Examples include large scale sequence data from genomics and market data from economics. In genomics, researchers search for copy number variations (CNVs) by examining hundreds of thousands of measurements of biomarkers along the whole genome. In financial engineering, it is useful to identify and interpret abrupt changes of stock prices. In these examples, a premier goal is to discover structural changes from massive sequence data. In this collaborative project, the investigators intend to develop and study theoretically sound and practically flexible and portable strategies to analyze complex sequence data and apply the proposed algorithms to real data for scientific discovery. 
 
The investigators aim to develop scalable and flexible algorithms to identify and infer structural changes in contemporary high-throughput data. In particular, they will work on (a) fast change-point detection techniques which are flexible enough to handle non-Gaussian data and dependent data; (b) new statistical framework for joint analysis of multiple-sequence data; (c) theoretical foundations for inference of change points which can assign significant levels for detected change points and achieves the control of false discovery rate (FDR); (d) applications to CNV data for scientific discoveries. Moreover, the investigators plan to develop user-friendly and publicly accessible software for the proposed methods so that researchers can apply the proposed methodologies directly to their research problems.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of this project are to design and implement new scalable algorithms to detect structural changes in modern big and complex data, to establish theoretical foundation to these new methods, and to apply them to real applications for scientific discoveries. 

 

It is a fundamental problem to uncover structural changes in big and complex data. Due to the tremendous sizes and complex noise distributions featured in modern data, scalability and flexibility are two main concerns in developing change-point detection and segment detection algorithms. We have completed several of projects developing fast change-point detection algorithms for big and non-Gaussian data. In Xiao et al. (2019), we proposed modSaRa2 that can incorporate a non-Gaussian sequence, called B-Allele Frequency (BAF), for copy number variant (CNV) detection. In Shin et al. (2020), we developed a backward detection algorithm for change-point detection. In Hao et al. (2020), we proposed a nonparametric segment detection algorithm, called super scalable short segment (4S) algorithm, which requires minimal condition on the noise distribution and is robust against heavy-tailed distributions. All algorithms are scalable with linear complexity or close to linear complexity with respect to the length of data sequence. In particular, the 4S algorithm costs less than 5n operations to analyze a sequence of length n. More importantly, it is equipped with an inference framework, which gives a significant level for each detected segment. Three R packages modSaRa2, bwd, and SSSS implementing the methods in these three works have been developed and published.

 

During the project period, the PIs have involved graduate and undergraduate students in the research and provided training and guidance for their career development. They have helped to develop the curriculum of Statistics and Data Science undergraduate program, founded in 2018, at the University of Arizona. In particular, they have designed and taught a new undergraduate course on statistical computing. They have founded and been coaching math clubs in local elementary schools. The PIs have been invited to present their research at multiple domestic and international conferences, and seminars.

 


Last Modified: 09/22/2021
Modified by: Yue Niu
